[MRS . HUMPHRY WARD]113-mrs . humphry ward [I]0-i

[Two old labourers]276-two old labourers came out of [the lane leading to [Great End Farm]1-great end farm]277-the lane leading to great end farm . [Both]278-both carried bags slung on sticks over [their]278-both shoulders . [One]279-one , [the eldest and tallest]280-the eldest and tallest , was [a handsome fellow , with regular features and a delicately humorous mouth]281-a handsome fellow , with regular features and a delicately humorous mouth . [His]279-one stoop and [his]279-one slouching gait , the gray locks also , which straggled from under [his]279-one broad hat , showed [him]279-one [an old man]282-an old man -- probably very near [his]279-one old - age pension . But [he]279-one carried still with [him]279-one a look of youth , and [he]279-one had been a splendid creature in [his]279-one time . [The other]283-the other was short of stature and of neck , bent besides by field work . [A broadly - built , clumsy man , with something gnome - like about [him]279-one]284-a broadly - built , clumsy man , with something gnome - like about him , and the cheerful look of [one whose country nerves had never known the touch of worry or long sickness]285-one whose country nerves had never known the touch of worry or long sickness . The name of [the taller man]286-the taller man was [Peter Halsey]114-halsey , and [Joseph Batts]115-batts was [[his]114-halsey companion]287-his companion .

It was a fine July evening , with a cold north wind blowing from [the plain]288-the plain which lay stretched to [their]289-their right . Under the unclouded sun , which by its own ' sun - time " had only reached half - past four in the afternoon , though the clock in [the village church]3143-the village church had already struck half - past five , the air was dry and parching , and [the fields]3144-the fields all round , [the road]3145-the road itself , and the dusty hedges showed signs of long drought .[286-the taller man]

" It du want rain , "[114-halsey] said [Peter Halsey]114-halsey , looking at a crop of oats through an open gate , " it du want rain--_bad _ . "[114-halsey]

" Aye ! "[283-the other] said [the other]283-the other , " that it du . [Muster Shenstone]116-muster shenstone had better ' a read the prayer for rain lasst Sunday , [I]283-the other 'm thinkin ' , than all them long ones as ee _ did _ read . "[283-the other]

[Halsey]114-halsey was silent a moment , [his]114-halsey half - smiling eyes glancing from side to side . At last [he]114-halsey said slowly,--

" [We]289-their du be prayin ' a lot about ower sins , and [Muster Shenstone]116-muster shenstone is allus preachin ' about ['em]3146-'em . But it 's the sins o ' the _ Garmins _ [I]114-halsey be thinkin ' of . If it had n't a bin for the sins o ' [the Garmins]117-the garmins [[my]114-halsey [Tom]118-mr. wellin]3147-my tom would n't [ha]3148-ha ' lost ' is right hand . "[114-halsey]

" An ' ower [Jim]114-halsey would n't be goin' into [them]3149-them trenches next November as ever is , "[115-batts] put in [Batts]115-batts . " It 's the sins o ' [the Garmins]117-the garmins as [ha]3148-ha ' done _ that _ , an ' nothin' as [you]114-halsey or [I]115-batts ha ' done , [Peter]114-halsey . "[115-batts]

[Halsey]114-halsey shook [his]114-halsey head assentingly .

" Noa -- for all that pratin ' , [pacifist chap]3150-pacifist chap was sayin ' lasst week . [I]114-halsey did n't believe a word [ee]3150-pacifist chap said . ' Yis , ' [I]114-halsey says , ' if [you]114-halsey want this war to stop , [I]114-halsey 'm o ' [your]114-halsey mind , ' [I]114-halsey says , ' but when [you]114-halsey tells [me]114-halsey as _ [England]2-england _ done it -- [you'm--]114-halsey ' "[114-halsey]

[The short man]291-the short man burst into a cackling laugh .

" ' [You'm]114-halsey [a liar]3151-a liar ! ' Did [you]114-halsey say that , [Peter]114-halsey ? "[291-the short man]

[Peter]114-halsey fenced a little .

" There be more ways nor one o ' speakin ' [your]114-halsey mind , "[291-the short man] [he]291-the short man said at last . " But [I]291-the short man stood up to un . Did [you]114-halsey hear , [Batts]115-batts , as [Great End Farm]3152-great end farm is let ? "[291-the short man]

[The old man]292-the old man turned an animated look on [[his]292-the old man companion]287-his companion .

" Well , for sure ! "[115-batts] said [Batts]115-batts , astonished . " An ' who 's [the man]3153-the man ? "[115-batts]

" [It]3154-it 's not [a man]3155-a man . [It]3154-it 's [a woman]3156-a woman . "[292-the old man]

" [A woman]3156-a woman ! "[115-batts] repeated [Batts]115-batts , wondering . " Well , these be funny times to live in , when [the women]3158-the women go ridin ' astride an ' hay - balin ' , an ' steam - ploughin ' , an ' [the Lord]3159-the lord knows what . And now [they]3158-the women must be takin ' [the farms]3160-the farms , and turnin ' out [the men]3161-the men . Well , for sure . "[115-batts]

A mild and puzzled laughter crossed [the speaker]294-the speaker 's face .

[Halsey]114-halsey nodded .

" An ' now [they]3158-the women 've got the vote . That 's the top on't ! [[My]292-the old man old missis]3162-my old missis , [she]3162-my old missis talks [poltiks]3163-poltiks now to [me]292-the old man of a night . [I]292-the old man do n't mind [her]3162-my old missis , now [the childer]3164-the childer be all gone . But [I]292-the old man 'd [ha]3165-ha ' bid [her]3162-my old missis mind [her]3162-my old missis own business when [they]3158-the women was yoong an ' wanted seein ' to . "[292-the old man]

" Now , what can [a woman]3156-a woman knoa about poltiks ? "[115-batts] said [Batts]115-batts , still in the same tone of pleasant rumination . " It is n't in [natur]3-natur . _ [We]3167-we _ warn't given the producin ' o ' [the babies]3168-the babies -- [we'd]3167-we [ha]3165-ha ' cried out if [we]3167-we ' ad been ! "[115-batts]

A chuckle passed from [one old man]295-one old man to the other .

" Well , onyways [the women]3158-the women is all in a flutter about the votin ' , "[114-halsey] said [Halsey]114-halsey , lighting [his]114-halsey pipe with old hands that shook . " An ' there 's [chaps]3170-chaps already coomin ' round lookin ' out for it . "[114-halsey]

" [You]115-batts bet there is ! "[115-batts] was [Batts]115-batts 's amused reply . " But [they]3158-the women 'll take [their]3158-the women toime , will [the women]3158-the women . ' Do n't [you]115-batts try to hustle - bustle [me]115-batts like [you]115-batts 're doin' , ' say [[my]115-batts missus]3172-my missus sharp - like to [a Labour chap]3173-a labour chap as coom round lasst week , 'cos [yo]115-batts ' wo n't get nothin' by it . ' And [she]296-this yoong woman worn't no more forthcomin ' to [the Conservative man]3174-the conservative man when [ee]3174-the conservative man called . "[115-batts]

" Will [she]296-this yoong woman do what _ [you]115-batts _ tell [her]296-this yoong woman , [Batts]115-batts ? "[114-halsey] asked [Halsey]114-halsey , with an evident interest in the question .

" Oh , [Lord]3175-lord , no ! "[115-batts] said [Batts]115-batts placidly , ' sha n't try . But now about [this yoong woman]296-this yoong woman an ' Great End?-- "[115-batts]

" Well , [I]115-batts ai n't heared much about [her]296-this yoong woman -- not yet awhile . But [they]3176-they say as [she]296-this yoong woman 's nice - lookin ' , an ' Muster Shentsone [ee]3174-the conservative man said as [she]296-this yoong woman 'd been to [college]3177-college somewhere , where [they]3176-they 'd larn't [her]296-this yoong woman farmin ' . "[115-batts]

[Batts]115-batts made a sound of contempt .

" [College]3177-college ! "[297-he] [he]297-he said , with a twitching of the broad nostrils which seemed to spread over half [his]297-he face . " _ [They]3176-they _ ca n't larn [yer]3174-the conservative man farmin ' ! "[297-he]

" [She]296-this yoong woman 's been on [a farm too somewhere near [Brighton]4-brighton]3179-a farm too somewhere near brighton , [Muster Shenstone]116-muster shenstone says , since [she]296-this yoong woman was at college ; and [ee]3174-the conservative man told [me]115-batts [she]296-this yoong woman do seem to be terr'ble full o ' new notions . "[115-batts]

" [She]296-this yoong woman 'd better be full o ' money , "[283-the other] said [the other]283-the other , cuttingly . " [Notions]120-notions is no good without money to ['em]3180-'em . "[283-the other]

" Aye , [they]120-notions 're wunnerfull costly things is notions . Yo'd better by a long way go by [the folk as know]3181-the folk as know . But [they]3176-they do say [she]296-this yoong woman 'll be payin ' good wages . "[115-batts]

" [I]115-batts dessay [she]296-this yoong woman will ! [She]296-this yoong woman 'll be obleeged . It 's [Hobson]121-hobson 's choice , as [you]115-batts might say ! "[115-batts] said [Batts]115-batts , chuckling again .

[Halsey]114-halsey was silent , and [the two old men]299-the two old men trudged on with cheerful countenances . Through the minds of both there ran pleasant thoughts of the contrast between the days before the war and the days now prevailing . [Both of [them]299-the two old men]300-both of them could remember a wage of fifteen and sixteen shillings a week . Then just before the war , it had risen to eighteen shillings and a pound . And now -- why the Wages Board for [Brookshire]5-brookshire had fixed thirty - three shillings as a weekly minimum , and a nine - hours ' day ! Prices were high , but they would go down some day ; and wages would not go down . [The old men]301-the old men could not have told exactly why this confidence lay so deep in [them]301-the old men ; but there it was , and it seemed to give a strange new stability and even dignity to life . [[Their]301-the old men sons]302-their sons were fighting ; and [they]301-the old men had the normal human affection for [[their]301-the old men sons]302-their sons . [They]301-the old men wished the war to end . But , after all , there was something to be said for the war . [They]299-the two old men -- [old Peter Halsey]114-halsey and [old Joe Batts]115-batts -- were more considered and more comfortable than [they]299-the two old men would have been before the war . And it was the consideration more even than the comfort that warmed [their]299-the two old men hearts .

The evening grew hotter , and the way to [the village]304-the village seemed long . [The old men]301-the old men were now too tired to talk ; till just as [they]301-the old men came in sight of [the first houses]306-the first houses , [they]301-the old men perceived [the village wagonette coming towards [them]301-the old men]307-the village wagonette coming towards them .

" There [she]3182-she be ! [I]114-halsey did hear as [Webb]122-jonathan webb wor to meet [her]3182-she at [the station]3183-the station . [He]122-jonathan webb 's took [her]3182-she over once before , "[114-halsey] said [old Halsey]114-halsey , raising [his]114-halsey eyes for a moment and then dropping them again . [Batts]115-batts did the same . The glance was momentary . But [both men]308-both men had the same impression of [a pleasant - faced young woman]309-a pleasant - faced young woman sitting erect behind [Jonathan Webb]122-jonathan webb , [the decrepit driver of [the wagonette]311-the wagonette]310-the decrepit driver of the wagonette , and looking straight at [them]308-both men as [they]308-both men passed [her]309-a pleasant - faced young woman . There was a general effect of youth and bright colour ; of pale brown hair , too , over very dark eyes .

" Aye , [she]3182-she be quite nice - lookin ' , "[115-batts] said [Batts]115-batts , with unction , " rayther uncommon . [She]3182-she minds [me]115-batts summat o ' [my]115-batts missis when [she]3182-she wor [a young ' un]3184-a young ' un . "[115-batts] [Halsey]114-halsey 's mouth twitched a little , but though [his]114-halsey thoughts were ironical , [he]114-halsey said nothing . It was generally admitted by [the older people]312-the older people that [Mrs. Batts]123-mrs. batts had been through many years [the village]304-the village beauty , but [her]123-mrs. batts fall from [that high place]314-that high place was now of such ancient date that it seemed foolish of [Batts]123-mrs. batts to be so fond of referring to it .

[The wagonette]311-the wagonette passed on . [The woman sitting in]316-the woman sitting in [it]311-the wagonette carefully took note of the scene around [her]309-a pleasant - faced young woman , in a mood of mingled hope and curiosity . [She]309-a pleasant - faced young woman was to live in [this valley]317-this valley without [a stream]318-a stream , under these high chalk downs with [[their]319-their hanging woods]320-their hanging woods , and within a mile or so of [the straggling village [she]309-a pleasant - faced young woman had just driven through]321-the straggling village she had just driven through . At last , after much wandering , [she]309-a pleasant - faced young woman was to find [a home]322-a home -- [a real home of [her]309-a pleasant - faced young woman own]323-a real home of her own . The word " [home]3185-home "[309-a pleasant - faced young woman] had not meant much -- or much at least that was agreeable -- to [her]309-a pleasant - faced young woman , till now . [Her]309-a pleasant - faced young woman large but handsome mouth took a bitter fold as [she]309-a pleasant - faced young woman thought over various past events .

Now [they]324-they had left [the village]304-the village behind , and were passing through fields that were soon to be [[her]309-a pleasant - faced young woman fields]326-her fields . [Her]309-a pleasant - faced young woman keen eyes appraised the crops standing in them . [She]309-a pleasant - faced young woman had paid [the family of [[her]309-a pleasant - faced young woman predecessor]328-her predecessor]327-the family of her predecessor a good price for [them]327-the family of her predecessor , but [they]327-the family of her predecessor were worth it . And just ahead , on [her]309-a pleasant - faced young woman left , was [a wide stretch of newly - ploughed land rising towards [a bluff of grassy down - land on the horizon]330-a bluff of grassy down - land on the horizon]329-a wide stretch of newly - ploughed land rising towards a bluff of grassy down - land on the horizon . [The ploughed land]331-the ploughed land [itself]331-the ploughed land had been down up to a few months before this date ; thin pasture for a few sheep , through many generations . [She]309-a pleasant - faced young woman thought with eagerness of the crops [she]309-a pleasant - faced young woman was going to make it bear , in the coming year . Wheat , or course . The wheat crops all round [the village]304-the village were really magnificent . This was going to be the resurrection year for English farming , after fifty years of " death and damnation"--comparatively[309-a pleasant - faced young woman] . And there would be many good years to come after .

Yes , [Mr. Thomas Wellin]118-mr. wellin , whose death had thrown [the farm which [she]309-a pleasant - faced young woman had now taken on the market]333-the farm which she had now taken on the market , had done well for [the land]334-the land . And it was not [his]118-mr. wellin fault but [the landlord]335-the landlord 's that [the farmhouse and buildings]336-the farmhouse and buildings had been allowed to fall into such a state . [Mr. Wellin]118-mr. wellin had not wanted [the house]337-the house , since [he]118-mr. wellin was only working [the land]334-the land temporarily in addition to [[his]118-mr. wellin own farm]339-his own farm half a mile away . But [the owner]340-the owner , [Colonel Shepherd]124-colonel shepherd , ought to have looked after [the farmhouse]341-the farmhouse and [buildings]342-buildings better . Still , [they]340-the owner were making [her]309-a pleasant - faced young woman a fair allowance for repairs .

[She]309-a pleasant - faced young woman was longing to know how [the workmen from [Millsboro]6-millsboro]343-the workmen from millsboro had been getting on . [Hastings]125-mr. hastings , [[the Wellins]126-the wellins ' former bailiff]344-the wellins ' former bailiff , now temporarily [hers]309-a pleasant - faced young woman , had promised to stay behind that evening to meet [her]309-a pleasant - faced young woman at [the farm]345-the farm . [She]309-a pleasant - faced young woman only meant to insist on what was absolutely necessary . Even if [she]309-a pleasant - faced young woman had wished for anything more , the lack of labour would have prevented it .

The old horse jogged on , and presently from a row of limes beside [the road]3145-the road , a wave of fragrance , evanescent and delicious , passed over [the carriage]347-the carriage . [Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson sniffed it with delight . " But one has never _ enough _ of it ! "[127-miss henderson] [she]127-miss henderson thought discontentedly . And then [she]127-miss henderson remembered how as [a child]348-a child -- in [far - away [Sussex]7-sussex]349-far - away sussex -- [she]127-miss henderson used to press [her]127-miss henderson face into the lime - blossom in [[[her]127-miss henderson uncle]350-her uncle 's garden]351-her uncle 's garden -- passionately , greedily , trying to get from it a greater pleasure than it would ever yield . For the more [she]127-miss henderson tried to compel it , by a kind of violence , the more it escaped [her]127-miss henderson . [She]127-miss henderson used to envy the bees lying drunk among the blooms . [They]352-they at least were surfeited and satisfied .

It struck [her]127-miss henderson that there was a kind of parable in it of [her]127-miss henderson whole life -- so far .

But now there was a new world opening . The past was behind [her]127-miss henderson . [She]127-miss henderson drew [herself]127-miss henderson stiffly erect , conscious through every limb of youth and strength , and filled with a multitude of vague hopes . Conscious , too , of the three thousand pounds that [Uncle Robert]128-uncle robert had so opportunely left [her]127-miss henderson . [She]127-miss henderson had never realized that money could make so much difference ; and [she]127-miss henderson thought gratefully of [the elderly bachelor]353-the elderly bachelor , [[[her]127-miss henderson mother]354-her mother 's brother]355-her mother 's brother , who had unexpectedly remembered [her]127-miss henderson . It had enabled [her]127-miss henderson to get [her]127-miss henderson year 's training , and to take [this farm]356-this farm with a proper margin of capital . [She]127-miss henderson wished [she]127-miss henderson had been able to tell [Uncle Robert]128-uncle robert before [he]128-uncle robert died what it meant to [her]127-miss henderson .

[They]357-they passed one or two pairs of [labourers]358-labourers going [home]3185-home , then [a group of [girls in overalls]361-girls in overalls]360-a group of girls in overalls , then [a spring cart]362-a spring cart containing [four workmen behind a ragged pony]363-four workmen behind a ragged pony , no doubt [[the builder]364-the builder 's men who had been at work on [the Great End repairs]366-the great end repairs]365-the builder 's men who had been at work on the great end repairs . [Some of [them]357-they]367-some of them perhaps would soon be in [her]127-miss henderson employ . [She]127-miss henderson would be settling all that in a week or two .

Ah , there was [the house]337-the house . [She]127-miss henderson leant forward and saw [it]337-the house lying under [the hill]369-the hill , [the woods on the slope coming down to the back of [it]337-the house]370-the woods on the slope coming down to the back of it . Yes , it was certainly a lonely situation . That was why [the house]337-the house , [the farm lands]372-the farm lands , too , had been so long unlet , till old Wellin , [[the farm]345-the farm 's nearest neighbour]374-the farm 's nearest neighbour , having made a good deal of money , had rented [the land]334-the land from [Colonel Shepherd]124-colonel shepherd , to add to [his]124-colonel shepherd own . [The farm buildings]376-the farm buildings , too , [he]124-colonel shepherd had made some use of , keeping carts and machines , and certain stores [there]377-there . But [the house]337-the house [he]124-colonel shepherd had refused to have any concern with . [It]337-the house had remained empty and locked up for a good many years .

[The wagonette]311-the wagonette turned into [the rough road leading through the middle of a fine field of oats to [the house]337-the house]380-the rough road leading through the middle of a fine field of oats to the house . [The field]382-the field was gaily splashed with poppies , which ran , too , along the edges of the crop , swayed by the evening breeze , and flaming in the level sun . Though lonesome and neglected , [the farm]345-the farm in [July]8-july was a pleasant and picturesque object . [It]345-the farm stood high and the air about [it]345-the farm blew keen and fresh . [The chalk hill]384-the chalk hill curved picturesquely round [it]345-the farm , and [the friendly woods]385-the friendly woods ran down behind to keep [it]345-the farm company . [Rachel Henderson]129-rachel , in pursuit of that campaign [she]129-rachel was always now waging against a natural optimism , tried to make [herself]129-rachel imagine it in winter -- the leafless trees , [the solitary road]386-the solitary road , [the treeless pasture]387-the treeless pasture or [arable fields]388-arable fields , that stretched westward in front of [the farm]345-the farm , covered perhaps with snow ; and [the distant stretches of [the plain]288-the plain]390-the distant stretches of the plain . [She]129-rachel [herself]129-rachel , in [the old wagonette]395-the old wagonette , seemed the only living thing .

No , there was [a man emerging from [the farm]345-the farm - gate]396-a man emerging from the farm - gate , and coming to meet [her]129-rachel -- [the bailiff]398-the bailiff , [George Hastings]130-george hastings . " Yon 's Muster [Hastings]130-george hastings , "[122-jonathan webb] said [Jonathan Webb]122-jonathan webb , turning on [her]129-rachel a benevolent and wrinkled countenance , with two bright red spots in the midst of each weather - beaten cheek . " [I]127-miss henderson 'm afraid [I]127-miss henderson have n't as much to show [you]129-rachel , [miss]3186-miss , as [I]127-miss henderson 'd like , "[127-miss henderson] said [Hastings]127-miss henderson , as [he]292-the old man helped [her]129-rachel to alight . [Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson replied civilly but decidedly that somehow or other the work would have to be done . If [Colonel Shepherd]124-colonel shepherd could n't find the wages , [she]129-rachel must pay the difference . Get in some time , during August , [she]129-rachel must .

[The bailiff]398-the bailiff looked at [her]129-rachel with a little sluggish surprise . [They]410-they turned to the right up [a stony pitch]411-a stony pitch , through a dilapidated gate , and so into [the quadrangle of [the farm]345-the farm]412-the quadrangle of the farm . [The house]337-the house was little more than [a large cottage built in [the shabbiest way]423-the shabbiest way forty years ago , and of far less dignity than the fine old barn on which [it]337-the house looked]422-a large cottage built in the shabbiest way forty years ago , and of far less dignity than the fine old barn on which it looked . [Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson stepped up to [the house]337-the house and looked at [it]337-the house .

" [It]337-the house is a poor place ! "[127-miss henderson] [she]127-miss henderson said discontentedly ; " and [those men]3190-those men do n't seem to have done much to [it]337-the house yet . "[127-miss henderson]

[Hastings]127-miss henderson admitted it . But [they]428-they had done a little , [he]429-he said , shamefacedly , and [he]429-he unlocked the door . [Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson lingered outside a moment .

" [I]127-miss henderson never noticed , "[127-miss henderson] [she]127-miss henderson said , " that [the living room]3191-the living room goes right through . What draughts there 'll be in the winter ! "[127-miss henderson]

For as [she]127-miss henderson stood looking into the curtainless window that fronted [the farm - yard]430-the farm - yard , [she]127-miss henderson saw through it a further window at the back of [the room]431-the room , and beyond that a tree . Both windows were large and seemed to take up most of the wall on either side of [the small room]432-the small room . The effect was peculiarly comfortless , as though [no one living in]433-no one living in [the room]431-the room could possibly enjoy any shred of privacy . There were no cosy corners in [it]431-the room anywhere , and [Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson 's fancy imagined rows of faces looking in .

Inside a little papering and whitewashing had been done , but certainly [the place]435-the place looked remarkably unviting . [A narrow passage]436-a narrow passage ran from front to back , on one side of which was [the living room]3191-the living room with the two windows , while on the other were [the kitchen and scullery]438-the kitchen and scullery . [Upstairs]439-upstairs there were [two good - sized bedrooms]440-two good - sized bedrooms with [a small third room]441-a small third room in [a lean - to]442-a lean - to at the back , the lower part of which was occupied by [a wash - house]443-a wash - house . Through the windows could be seen [a neglected bit of garden]444-a neglected bit of garden , and [an untidy orchard]445-an untidy orchard .

But when [she]127-miss henderson had wandered about [the rooms]446-the rooms a little , [Rachel Henderson]129-rachel 's naturally buoyant temperament reasserted itself . [She]127-miss henderson had brought some bright patterns of distemper with [her]127-miss henderson which [she]127-miss henderson gave to [Hastings]127-miss henderson with precise instructions . [She]127-miss henderson had visions of casement curtains to hide the nakedness of the big windows with warm serge curtains to draw over them in the winter . The floors must be stained . There should be a deep Indian - red drugget in [the sitting - room]447-the sitting - room , with pigeon - blue walls , and [she]127-miss henderson thought complacently of the bits of old furniture [she]127-miss henderson had been collecting , which were stored in [[a friend]448-a friend 's flat in [town]450-town]449-a friend 's flat in town . An old dresser , a grandfather 's clock , some bits of brass , two arm - chairs , an old oak table -- it would all look very nice when it was done , and would cost little . Then [the bedrooms]451-the bedrooms . [She]127-miss henderson had brought with [her]127-miss henderson some rolls of flowery paper . [She]127-miss henderson ran to fetch them from the wagonette , and pinned some pieces against the wall . [The larger room with the south aspect]452-the larger room with the south aspect should be [Janet]131-janet 's . [She]127-miss henderson would take [the north room]453-the north room for [herself]127-miss henderson . [She]127-miss henderson saw [them]454-them both in [her]127-miss henderson mind 's eye already comfortably furnished ; above all fresh and bright . There should be no dirt or dinginess in [the house]337-the house , if [she]127-miss henderson could help it . In the country whitewash and distemper are cheap .

Then [Hastings]127-miss henderson followed [her]127-miss henderson about through [the farm buildings]376-the farm buildings , where [her]127-miss henderson quick eye , trained in modern ways , perceived a number of small improvements to be made that [he]457-he would never have noticed . [She]127-miss henderson was always ready , [he]457-he saw , to spend money on things that would save labour or lessen dirt . But [she]127-miss henderson was not extravagant , and looking through the list of [her]127-miss henderson directions and commissions , as [he]457-he hastily jotted them down , [he]457-he admitted to [himself]457-he that [she]127-miss henderson seemed to know what [she]127-miss henderson was about . And being [an honest man]458-an honest man [himself]457-he , and good - tempered , though rather shy and dull , [he]457-he presently recognized the same qualities of honesty and good temper in [her]127-miss henderson ; and took to [her]127-miss henderson . Insensibly [their]459-their tone to [each other]460-each other grew friendly . Though [he]457-he was temporarily in [[the landlord]335-the landlord 's employ]462-the landlord 's employ , [he]457-he had been for some years in the service of [the Wellin family]463-the wellin family . Half - consciously [he]457-he contrasted [Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson 's manner to [him]457-he with [theirs]463-the wellin family . In [his]457-he own view [he]457-he had been worse treated than [an ordinary farm labourer]464-an ordinary farm labourer throughout [his]457-he farming life , though [he]457-he had more education , and was expected naturally to have more brains and foresight than [the labourer]465-the labourer . [He]457-he was a little better paid ; but [his]457-he work and that of [[his]457-he wife]466-his wife was never done . [He]457-he had got little credit for success and all the blame for failure . And [the Wellin women - folk]467-the wellin women - folk had looked down on [[his]457-he wife]466-his wife and [himself]457-he . A little patronage sometimes , and worthless gifts , that burnt in the taking ; but no common feeling , no real respect . But [Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson was different . [His]457-he rather downtrodden personality felt a stimulus . [He]457-he began to hope that when [she]127-miss henderson came into possession [she]127-miss henderson would take [him]457-he on . [A woman]3156-a woman could not possibly make anything of Great End without [a bailiff]470-a bailiff !

[Her]127-miss henderson " nice "[127-miss henderson] looks , no doubt , counted for something . [Her]127-miss henderson face was , perhaps , a little too full for beauty -- the delicately coloured cheeks and the large smiling mouth . But [her]127-miss henderson brown eyes were very fine , with very dark pupils , and marked eyebrows ; and [her]127-miss henderson nose and chin , with their soft , blunted lines , seemed to promise laughter and easy ways . [She]127-miss henderson was very lightly and roundly made ; and everything about [her]127-miss henderson , [her]127-miss henderson step , [her]127-miss henderson sunburn , [her]127-miss henderson freckles , [her]127-miss henderson evident muscular strength , spoke of open - air life and physical exercise . Yet , for all this general aspect of [a comely country - woman]471-a comely country - woman , there was much that was sharply sensitive and individual in the face . Even [a stranger]472-a stranger might well feel that its tragic , as well as its humorous or tender possibilities , would have to be reckoned with .

" All right ! [Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson made another quick movement . [She]127-miss henderson said nothing , however . [She]127-miss henderson was staring at [the woods]485-the woods , which shone in the glow now steadily creeping up [the hill]369-the hill , and [Hastings]127-miss henderson thought [she]127-miss henderson was protesting from the scenery point of view .

" Well , [the Government]10-the government must have the wood , "[487-he] [he]487-he said , with resignation . " [We]3218-we 've got to win the war . But it does seem a pity . "[487-he]

" [I]127-miss henderson do n't know that [I]127-miss henderson should have taken [the farm]345-the farm , "[127-miss henderson] [she]127-miss henderson said , under [her]127-miss henderson breath--

" If [you]487-he had known ? [I]127-miss henderson wish [I]127-miss henderson 'd thought to tell [you]487-he . But it was really only settled a few days ago . "[127-miss henderson]

" [I]127-miss henderson do n't like having [a lot of [strange men]3221-strange men about [the farm]345-the farm]3220-a lot of strange men about the farm , "[127-miss henderson] [she]127-miss henderson said abruptly , " especially when [I]127-miss henderson have [girls]3223-girls to look after . " Oh , [the camp]3224-the camp 's a long way from [the farm]345-the farm , "[487-he] [he]487-he said consolingly . " And [these woods]3212-these woods will come last . "[487-he]

Still [Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson 's face did not quite recover its cheerfulness . [She]127-miss henderson looked at [her]127-miss henderson watch .

" Do n't let [me]487-he keep [you]487-he , [Mr. Hastings]125-mr. hastings . [I]487-he 'll lock up [the house]337-the house , if [you]487-he 'll tell [me]487-he where to leave the key . "[487-he]

[He]487-he showed [her]127-miss henderson where to put it , in a corner of [the stable]488-the stable , for [him]487-he to find on the morrow . Then , in [her]127-miss henderson rapid way , [Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson offered [him]487-he the post of bailiff on [the farm]345-the farm , from the date of [her]127-miss henderson entry . [He]487-he agreed at once ; [his]487-he salary was settled , and [he]487-he departed with a more cheerful aspect than when [he]487-he arrived . The hopefulness and spring of youth had long since left [him]487-he , and [he]487-he had dreaded the new experience of this first meeting with [a woman]3156-a woman - farmer , from whom [he]487-he desired employment simply because [he]487-he was very badly off , [he]487-he was getting old , and [[Mr. Wellin]118-mr. wellin 's widow]491-mr. wellin 's widow had treated [him]487-he shabbily . [He]487-he had lost [his]487-he nerve for new ventures . But [Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson had made things easy . [She]127-miss henderson had struck [him]487-he as considerate and sensible -- a " good sort . "[127-miss henderson] [He]487-he would do [his]487-he best for [her]127-miss henderson .

[Rachel Henderson]129-rachel , left to [herself]129-rachel , did not immediately re - enter [the house]337-the house . [She]129-rachel went with a face on which the cloud still rested to look at the well which was to be found under [the cart - shed]424-the cart - shed , at [the eastern end of [the house]337-the house]494-the eastern end of the house .

[It]424-the cart - shed was covered with a wooden lid which [she]129-rachel removed . Under the shed roof there was but little light left . A faint gleam showed the level of the water , which , owing to the long drought , was very low . [Hastings]127-miss henderson had told [her]129-rachel that [the well]496-the well was extremely deep---150 feet at least , and inexhaustible . The water was chalky but good . It would have to be pumped up every morning for the supply of [the house]337-the house and [stables]498-stables .

[The well]496-the well had a brick margin . [Rachel]129-rachel sat down upon [it]496-the well , [her]129-rachel eyes upon that distant gleam below . The dusk was fast possessing itself of all [the farm]345-the farm , and an evening wind was gustily blowing through [the cart - shed]424-the cart - shed , playing with some old guano sacks that had been left there , and whistling round the corners of [the house]337-the house . Outside , [Rachel]129-rachel could hear the horse fidgeting , and [old Jonathan]122-jonathan webb coughing -- no doubt as a signal to [her]129-rachel that [she]129-rachel had kept [him]122-jonathan webb long enough .

Still , [she]129-rachel sat bent together on the margin of the well . Then [she]129-rachel drew off [her]129-rachel glove , and felt for something in the leather bag [she]129-rachel carried on [her]129-rachel wrist . [She]129-rachel took it out , and the small object sparkled a little as [she]129-rachel held it poised for a moment -- as though considering . Then with a rapid movement , [she]129-rachel bent over the well , and dropped it into the water . There was a slight splash .

[Rachel Henderson]129-rachel raised [herself]129-rachel and stood up .

" That 's done with ! "[129-rachel] [she]129-rachel said to [herself]129-rachel , with a straightening of all [her]129-rachel young frame .

Yet all the way back to [London]11-london [she]129-rachel was tormented by thoughts of what [she]129-rachel had declared was " done with "[129-rachel] ; of scenes and [persons]503-persons , that is , which [she]129-rachel was determined to forget , and had just formally renounced for ever by [her]129-rachel symbolic action at the well .

II

" [You]129-rachel do seem to have hit on a rather nice spot , [Rachel]129-rachel , though lonesome , "[127-miss henderson] said [[Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson 's friend]504-miss henderson 's friend and partner , [Janet Leighton]131-janet , as [they]505-they stood on the front steps of [Great End Farm]1-great end farm , surveying the scene outside , on an August evening , about a week after [she]504-miss henderson 's friend and [Rachel]129-rachel had arrived with [their]505-they furniture and personal belongings to take possession of [the farm]345-the farm .

During that week [they]505-they had both worked hard -- from dawn till dark , both outside and in . The harvest was in full swing , and as the dusk was filling , [Janet Leighton]131-janet , who had just returned [herself]131-janet from [the fields]3144-the fields , could watch the scene going on in [the wheat - field]481-the wheat - field beyond [the farm - yard]430-the farm - yard , where , as the reaping machine steadily pared away the remaining square of wheat , [two or three men]510-two or three men and [boys with guns]511-boys with guns lay in wait outside [the square]512-the square for the rabbits as [they]510-two or three men bolted from [their]510-two or three men fast lessening shelter . The gold and glow of harvest was on [the fields]3144-the fields and in the air . At last the sun had come back to [a sodden land]514-a sodden land , after weeks of cold and drenching showers which , welcomed in June , had by the middle of August made all [England]2-england tremble for the final fate of the gorgeous crops then filling [the largest area ever tilled on [British soil]516-british soil]515-the largest area ever tilled on british soil with their fat promise . Wheat , oats , and barley stood once more erect , roots were saved , and [the young vicar of [Ipscombe]12-ipscombe]517-the young vicar of ipscombe was reflecting as [he]517-the young vicar of ipscombe walked towards [Great End Farm]3152-great end farm that [his]517-the young vicar of ipscombe harvest festival sermon might now after all be rather easier to write than had seemed probable during the foregoing anxious weeks of chill and storm .

[Rachel Henderson]129-rachel , who had thrown [herself]129-rachel -- tired out -- into a chair in the sitting - room window , which was wide open , nodded as [she]129-rachel caught [[her]129-rachel friend]519-her friend 's remark and smiled . But [she]129-rachel did not want to talk . [She]129-rachel was in that state of physical fatigue when mere rest is a positive delight . The sun , the warm air , the busy harvest scene , and all the long hours of hard but pleasant work seemed to be still somehow in [her]129-rachel pulses , thrilling through [her]129-rachel blood . It was long since [she]129-rachel had known the acute physical pleasure of such a day ; but [her]129-rachel sense of it had conjured up involuntarily recollections of many similar days in a distant scene -- [great golden spaces]520-great golden spaces , blinding sun , and huge reaping machines , twice the size of that at work in [the field yonder]521-the field yonder . The recollections were unwelcome . [Thought]136-thought was unwelcome . [She]129-rachel wanted only food and sleep -- deep sleep -- renewing [her]129-rachel tired muscles , till the delicious early morning came round again , and [she]129-rachel was once more in [the fields]3144-the fields directing [[her]129-rachel team of [workers]524-workers]523-her team of workers .

" Why , there 's [the vicar]3228-the vicar ! "[131-janet] said [Janet Leighton]131-janet , perceiving the tall and willowy figure of [Mr. Shenstone]137-mr. shenstone , as [its owner]525-its owner stopped to speak to one of [the boys with the guns who were watching the game]526-the boys with the guns who were watching the game .

[Rachel]129-rachel looked round with a look of annoyance .

" Oh , [dear , what a bore]3229-dear , what a bore , "[129-rachel] [she]129-rachel said wearily . " [I]129-rachel suppose [I]129-rachel must go and tidy up . [Nobody]3230-nobody ought to be allowed to pay visits after five o'clock . "[129-rachel]

" [You]131-janet asked [him]3228-the vicar something about [a village woman to help]3231-a village woman to help , did n't [you]131-janet ? "[129-rachel]

" [I]129-rachel did , worse luck ! "[129-rachel] sighed [Rachel]129-rachel , gathering up [her]129-rachel sunbonnet and disappearing from the window . [Janet]131-janet heard [her]129-rachel go [upstairs]439-upstairs , and a hasty opening of cupboards overhead . [She]131-janet [herself]131-janet had come back an hour earlier from [the fields]3144-the fields than [Rachel]129-rachel in order to get supper ready , and had slipped a skirt over the khaki tunic and knickerbockers which were [her]131-janet dress -- and [[her]131-janet partner's]529-her partner's -- when at work on [the farm]345-the farm . [She]131-janet wondered mischievously what [Rachel]129-rachel would put on . That [her]131-janet character included an average dose of vanity , the natural vanity of [a handsome woman]531-a handsome woman , [[Rachel]129-rachel 's new friend]532-rachel 's new friend was well aware . But [Janet]131-janet , [[Rachel]129-rachel 's elder]533-rachel 's elder by five years , was only tenderly amused by it . All [Rachel]129-rachel 's foibles , as far as [she]131-janet knew [them]534-they , were pleasant to [her]131-janet . [They]534-they were in that early stage of a new friendship when all is glamour .

Yet [Janet]131-janet did sometimes reflect , " How little [I]131-janet really know about [her]129-rachel . [She]129-rachel is [a darling]3232-a darling -- but a mystery ! "[131-janet]

[They]534-they had met at college , taken [their]534-they farm training together , and fallen in love with [each other]460-each other . [Janet]131-janet had scarcely a relation in [the world]474-the world . [Rachel]129-rachel possessed , it seemed , [a brother in [Canada]13-canada]537-a brother in canada , another in [South Africa]14-south africa , and [some cousins whom [she]129-rachel scarcely knew]538-some cousins whom she scarcely knew , [children of [the uncle who had left [her]129-rachel three thousand pounds]540-the uncle who had left her three thousand pounds]539-children of the uncle who had left her three thousand pounds . [Each]541-each had been attracted by the loneliness of [the other]283-the other , and on leaving college nothing was more natural than [they]534-they should agree to set up together . [Rachel]129-rachel , as [the capitalist]543-the capitalist , was to choose [the farm]345-the farm and take command . [Janet]131-janet went to [a Cheshire dairy farm]545-a cheshire dairy farm for a time to get some further training in practical work ; and [she]131-janet was now responsible for [the dairy at [Great End]15-great end]546-the dairy at great end , with the housekeeping and the poultry thrown in . [She]131-janet was [a thin , tall woman with spectacles]547-a thin , tall woman with spectacles , and had just seen [her]131-janet thirty - second birthday . [Her]131-janet eyes were honest and clear , [her]131-janet mouth humorous . [She]131-janet never grudged [other women]548-other women [their]548-other women beauty or [their]548-other women success . It always seemed to [her]131-janet [she]131-janet had what [she]131-janet deserved .

Meanwhile [the vicar]3228-the vicar approached , and [Miss Leighton]133-miss leighton descended the steps and went to meet [him]3228-the vicar at the gate . [His]3228-the vicar aspect showed [him]3228-the vicar apologetic .

"[3228-the vicar]

"[3228-the vicar]

" What sort is the ghost ? "[131-janet] [Janet]131-janet inquired , as [she]131-janet pointed [him]3228-the vicar to a chair , devoutly hoping that [Rachel]129-rachel would hurry [herself]129-rachel .

[The vicar]3228-the vicar opened [his]3228-the vicar eyes a little . [Miss Leighton]133-miss leighton was , [he]3228-the vicar saw , [a lady]553-a lady , and perhaps clever . [These educated women in new professions]554-these educated women in new professions were becoming a very pressing and common fact ! As to the murder , [he]3228-the vicar explained that it had been just an ordinary poaching affair . [An old gamekeeper on [the Shepherd estate]556-the shepherd estate]555-an old gamekeeper on the shepherd estate had been attacked by a gang of [poachers]557-poachers in the winter of 1866 . [He]555-an old gamekeeper on the shepherd estate had been shot in [one of [the woods]485-the woods]558-one of the woods , and though mortally wounded had been able to drag [himself]555-an old gamekeeper on the shepherd estate to [the outskirts of [the farm]345-the farm where [his]555-an old gamekeeper on the shepherd estate strength had failed [him]555-an old gamekeeper on the shepherd estate]560-the outskirts of the farm where his strength had failed him . " [I]3228-the vicar ought n't to have told [you]129-rachel -- [I]3228-the vicar really ought n't ; just on [your]129-rachel settling in -- [I]3228-the vicar hope [you]129-rachel wo n't tell [Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson ? "[3228-the vicar]

[Janet]131-janet 's amused reply was interrupted by [Rachel]129-rachel 's entrance . [The vicar]3228-the vicar arose with eagerness to receive [her]129-rachel . The flush and heat of hard bodily work had passed away . [She]129-rachel had had time to plunge [her]129-rachel face into cold water and smooth [her]129-rachel hair . But the atmosphere of [the harvest field]583-the harvest field , its ripeness and glow , seemed to be still about [her]129-rachel . But [the vicar]3228-the vicar had forgotten [his]3228-the vicar classics . _ En revanche _ , however , [he]3228-the vicar was doing [his]3228-the vicar best to show [himself]3228-the vicar sympathetic and up - to - date with regard to [women]3203-women and [their]3203-women new spheres of work -- especially on [the land]334-the land . " [She]129-rachel comes from [Ralstone]20-ralstone , "[129-rachel] said [Rachel]129-rachel .

What [the vicar]3228-the vicar did think was that [he]3228-the vicar had never seen a smile transform a face so agreeably . And having begun to smile , [Rachel]129-rachel perversely continued it . [She]129-rachel walked to the gate with [[her]129-rachel visitor]616-her visitor , talking with irrelevant animation , inviting [him]616-her visitor to come the following day to help in the " carrying , "[129-rachel] asking questions about [the village]304-the village and [[its]304-the village people]618-its people , and graciously consenting to fix a day when [she]129-rachel and [[her]129-rachel friend]519-her friend would go to tea with [Miss Shenstone]139-miss shenstone at [the vicarage]620-the vicarage . [Janet Leighton]131-janet meanwhile watched it all . [She]131-janet had seen [Rachel]129-rachel treat [a new male acquaintance]622-a new male acquaintance before as [she]131-janet had just treated [the vicar]3228-the vicar . To begin with , the manners of an icicle ; then a sudden thaw , just in time to save the situation . [She]131-janet had come with amusement to the conclusion that , however really indifferent or capricious , [[her]131-janet new friend]624-her new friend could not in the long run resign [herself]624-her new friend to be disliked , even by [a woman]3156-a woman , and much more in the case of [a man]3155-a man . Was it vanity , or sex , or both ? Temperament perhaps ; the modern word which covers so much . [Janet]131-janet remembered [a little niece of [her]131-janet own who in [[her]131-janet mother]354-her mother 's absence entertained [a gentleman visitor]629-a gentleman visitor with great success]627-a little niece of her own who in her mother 's absence entertained a gentleman visitor with great success . [Janet Leighton]131-janet suspected that similar tales might have been told of [Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson in [her]127-miss henderson babyhood .

And yet impressions recurred to [her]131-janet of another kind -- of a sensitive , almost fierce delicacy -- a shrinking from the ugly or merely physical facts of life , as of one who had suffered some torment in connection with [them]630-they .

[Janet]131-janet 's eyes followed the curly brown head as [its possessor]631-its possessor came slowly back from the gate . [She]131-janet was thinking of a moment when , one evening , while [they]630-they were both still at college , [they]630-they had realized [their]630-they liking for [each other]460-each other , and had agreed to set up in partnership . Then [Rachel]129-rachel , springing to [her]129-rachel feet , with [her]129-rachel hands behind [her]129-rachel , and head thrown back , had said suddenly : " [I]129-rachel warn [you]131-janet , [I]129-rachel have a story . [I]129-rachel do n't want to tell [you]131-janet , to tell [anybody]3236-anybody . [I]129-rachel sha n't tell [you]131-janet . It 's done with . [I]129-rachel give [you]131-janet [my]129-rachel word that [I]129-rachel 'm not [a bad woman]3278-a bad woman . But if [you]131-janet do n't want to be [[my]129-rachel partner]3279-my partner on these terms , say so ! "[129-rachel]

And [Janet]131-janet had felt no difficulty whatever in becoming [[Rachel Henderson]129-rachel 's partner]633-rachel henderson 's partner on these terms . Nor had [she]131-janet ever yet regretted it .

[The light farm cart which had been sent to [the station]3183-the station for [stores]636-stores]634-the light farm cart which had been sent to the station for stores drove up to [the yard]610-the yard gate as [Rachel]129-rachel left [it]634-the light farm cart which had been sent to the station for stores . [She]129-rachel turned back to receive some parcels handed out by [the " exempted "[638-the " exempted " man who drove it] man who drove it]638-the " exempted " man who drove it , together with some letters which had been found lying at [the village post office]639-the village post office . Two of the letters were for [Janet]131-janet . [She]129-rachel sent them up to [the house]337-the house , and went [herself]129-rachel towards [the harvest field]583-the harvest field .

There [they]642-they stood -- [the rows of golden ' shocks " or stooks]3280-the rows of golden ' shocks " or stooks . [The ' shockers "]3281-the ' shockers "[3280-the rows of golden ' shocks " or stooks] had just finished [their]642-they day 's work . [She]129-rachel could hear the footsteps of the last batch , a cheerful chatter , while talk and laughter came softened through the evening air . [The man who had been driving the reaping machine]643-the man who had been driving the reaping machine was doing some rough repairs to it in a far corner of [the field]382-the field , with a view to the morrow , and [she]129-rachel caught sight of [[her]129-rachel new bailiff]645-her new bailiff , [Hastings]127-miss henderson , who had waited to see [everybody]404-everybody off , disappearing towards [[his]645-her new bailiff own cottage]647-his own cottage , which stood on [a lonely spur of the down]648-a lonely spur of the down . The light was fast going , but the deep glow of the western sky answered the paler gold of the new - made stubble and [the ranged stooks]649-the ranged stooks , while between rose the dark and splendid masses of [the woods]485-the woods .

[Rachel]129-rachel stood looking at the scene , possessed by a pleasure which in [her]129-rachel was always an ardour . [She]129-rachel felt nothing by halves . The pulse of life beat in [her]129-rachel still with an energy , a passion , that astonished [herself]129-rachel . [She]129-rachel was full of eagerness for [her]129-rachel new work and for success in it , full of desires , too , for vague , half - seen things , things [she]129-rachel had missed so Far -- [her]129-rachel own fault . But somewhere in the long , hidden years , [they]651-they must , [they]651-they should be waiting for [her]129-rachel .

The harvest was magnificent . [She]129-rachel had paid the Wellins a high price for the standing crops , but there was going to be a profit on [her]129-rachel bargain . [Her]129-rachel mind was full of schemes , if only [she]129-rachel could get the labour to carry them out . Farming was now on the up - grade . [She]129-rachel had come into [it]652-it at the very best moment , and [England]2-england would never let farming go down again , after the war , for [her]129-rachel own safety 's sake .

_ The War _ ! [She]129-rachel felt towards it as to [some distant force , which , so far as [she]129-rachel personally was concerned , was a force for good]653-some distant force , which , so far as she personally was concerned , was a force for good . Owing to the war , farming was booming all over [England]2-england , and [she]129-rachel was in the boom , taking advantage of it . Yet [she]129-rachel was ashamed to think of the war only in that way . [She]129-rachel tried to tame the strange ferment in [her]129-rachel blood , and could only do it by reminding [herself]129-rachel of [[Hastings]127-miss henderson 's wounded son]654-hastings 's wounded son , whose letter [he]654-hastings 's wounded son had showed [her]129-rachel . And then -- in imagination -- [she]129-rachel began to see [thousands of others like [him]654-hastings 's wounded son]655-thousands of others like him , in [hospital beds]656-hospital beds , or lying dead in [trampled fields]657-trampled fields . [Her]129-rachel mood softened , the tears came into [her]129-rachel eyes .

Suddenly -- a slight whimper -- [a child]348-a child 's whimper -- close beside [her]129-rachel . [She]129-rachel paused in amazement , looking round [her]129-rachel , till the whimper was renewed ; and there , almost at [her]129-rachel feet , cradled in the fragrant hollow of a wheat stook , [she]129-rachel saw [a tiny child]659-a tiny child -- [a baby about a year old]660-a baby about a year old , [a fair , plump thing]661-a fair , plump thing , just waking from sleep .

At sight of the face bending over [her]659-a tiny child , [the child]662-the child set up a louder cry , which was not angry , however , only forlorn . The tears welled fast into [her]662-the child blue eyes . [She]662-the child looked piteously at [Rachel]129-rachel .

" [Mummy]140-mummy , [mummy]3276-mummy ! "[662-the child]

" [[You]659-a tiny child poor little thing]3283-you poor little thing ! "[129-rachel] said [Rachel]129-rachel . " Whose are [you]3283-you poor little thing ? "[129-rachel]

One of [the village women who had been helping in the ' shocking]663-the village women who had been helping in the ' shocking , " [she]129-rachel supposed , had brought [the child]662-the child . [She]129-rachel had noticed [a little girl playing about the reapers]3285-a little girl playing about the reapers in the afternoon -- no doubt [an elder sister]3286-an elder sister brought to look after [the baby]3287-the baby . Between [the mother]3288-the mother and [the sister]3289-the sister there must have been some confusion , and one or other would come running back directly .[129-rachel]

But meanwhile [she]129-rachel took up [the child]662-the child , who at first resisted passionately , fighting with all its chubby strength against the strange arms . But [Rachel]129-rachel seemed to have a way with [her]662-the child -- a spell , which worked . [She]129-rachel bent over the little thing , soothing and cooing to [her]662-the child , and then finding a few crumbs of cake in the pocket of [her]129-rachel overall , the remains of [her]129-rachel own lunch in [the field]382-the field , [she]129-rachel daintily fed the rosy mouth , till the sobs ceased and [the child]662-the child stared upwards in a sleep wonder , [her]662-the child blue eyes held by the brown ones above [her]662-the child .

" Mummy ! "[662-the child] [she]662-the child repeated , still whimpering slightly .

" [Mummy]140-mummy 's coming , "[129-rachel] said [Rachel]129-rachel tenderly . " What [a duck it]3290-a duck it is ! "[129-rachel]

And bending , [she]129-rachel kissed the soft , downy cheek greedily , with the same ardour [she]129-rachel had just been throwing into [her]129-rachel own dreams of success .

[She]129-rachel carried [the child , now quiet and comforted]667-the child , now quiet and comforted , towards [the house]337-the house . The warm weight upon [her]129-rachel arms was delicious to [her]129-rachel . Only as [she]129-rachel neared the gate in the now moonlit dusk , [her]129-rachel lips quivered suddenly , and two tears rolled down [her]129-rachel cheeks .

" [I]129-rachel have n't carried [a child]348-a child , "[129-rachel] [she]129-rachel thought , ' since-- "[129-rachel]

Suddenly there was a shout from the farther gate of [the harvest field]583-the harvest field , and [a girl]670-a girl came running at top speed . It was [[the little one]671-the little one 's elder sister]672-the little one 's elder sister , and with a proper scolding , [Rachel]129-rachel gave up [her]129-rachel prize .

[The two land - girls]673-the two land - girls had finished giving food and water to the cattle and a special mush to [new - born calves]674-new - born calves . Everything was now in order for the night , and [Janet]131-janet , standing on the steps of [the farm - house]675-the farm - house , rang a bell , which meant that supper would be ready in a few minutes . [The two partners]676-the two partners and [[their]676-the two partners employees]677-their employees were soon gathered round the table in [the kitchen]3239-the kitchen , which was also [the dining - room]679-the dining - room . It was a cold meal of bacon , with lettuce , bread and jam , some tea made on a " [Tommy]118-mr. wellin 's cooker , "[131-janet] and potatoes which [Janet]131-janet , who was for [the present housekeeper and cook]680-the present housekeeper and cook , produced hot and steaming from the hay - box to which [she]131-janet had consigned [them]676-the two partners after the midday dinner . A small oil - lamp had been lit , and through the open windows afterglow and moonrise streamed in to mingle with its light . There was a pot of flowers on the table -- purple scabious , and tall cow - parsley , gathered from [the orchard]681-the orchard , where [no one]570-no one had yet had time to cut the ragged hay beneath the trees .

The scene was typical of [a new England]683-a new england . [Women]3203-women governing -- and [women]3203-women serving -- [they]673-the two land - girls were all alike making [their]673-the two land - girls way through new paths to new ends . It was no household in the ordinary sense . [The man]3153-the man was wanting . [The two elder women]687-the two elder women were bound to [the two younger]688-the two younger by a purely business tie , which might or might not develop into something more personal . [The two land - lasses]689-the two land - lasses had come to supper in [their]689-the two land - lasses tunics and breeches , while [Rachel Henderson]129-rachel and [Janet]131-janet had now both put on the coloured overalls which disguised the masculine garb beneath , and gave [them]676-the two partners something of the usual feminine air . [Rachel]129-rachel 's overall , indeed , was both pretty and artistic , embroidered a little here and there , and showing a sunburnt throat beneath the rounded chin .

The talk turned on the day 's work , the weather prospects , the vagaries of the cows at milking time , and those horrid little pests the " harvesters , "[676-the two partners] which haunt [the chalk soils]690-the chalk soils . The two " hands "[676-the two partners] were clear by now that [they]676-the two partners liked [Miss Leighton]133-miss leighton the best of [the two ladies]691-the two ladies , [they]676-the two partners hardly knew why . [Betty Rolfe]141-betty , [the younger of [them]691-the two ladies , who came from [Ralstone]20-ralstone]692-the younger of them , who came from ralstone , was [a taking creature , with deep black , or rather violet , eyes , small features framed in curly hair , and the bloom of ripe fruit]693-a taking creature , with deep black , or rather violet , eyes , small features framed in curly hair , and the bloom of ripe fruit . [She]141-betty was naturally full of laughter and talk , and only spoilt by [her]141-betty discoloured and uneven teeth , which showed the usual English neglect of such things in childhood .

[[Her]141-betty companion]473-her companion , [Jenny Harberton]142-janet , was a much more ordinary type , with broad cheeks , sandy hair , and a perpetual friendly grin , which generally served [her]473-her companion instead of speech , at least in [[her]473-her companion employer]695-her employer 's presence . [She]473-her companion was [a capital milker]696-a capital milker , and [a good honest child]697-a good honest child . [[Her]473-her companion people]698-her people lived in [the village]304-the village , and [[her]473-her companion forebears]700-her forebears had always lived [there]377-there . [They]698-her people were absolutely indigenous and autochthonous -- [a far older Brookshire family]702-a far older brookshire family than [any of [the dwellers in [the big houses about]705-the big houses about]704-the dwellers in the big houses about]703-any of the dwellers in the big houses about .

Then in the midst of a loving report by [Betty]141-betty on the virtues and docility of [a beautiful Jersey cow who was the pride of [[Miss Henderson]127-miss henderson 's new herd]707-miss henderson 's new herd]706-a beautiful jersey cow who was the pride of miss henderson 's new herd , [Janet Leighton]131-janet remembered one of [her]131-janet letters of the evening and drew it out of [her]131-janet pocket .

" Who do [you]131-janet think is going to be -- is already -- [the commandant of [the timber girls in [the new camp]3294-the new camp]3293-the timber girls in the new camp]3292-the commandant of the timber girls in the new camp ? "[131-janet]

[Rachel]129-rachel could n't guess .

" [You]131-janet remember [Mrs. Fergusson]143-mrs. fergusson -- at [College]22-college ? "[129-rachel]

" [The Irish lady]3295-the irish lady ? Perfectly . "[129-rachel]

"[129-rachel]

[Rachel]129-rachel looked irresponsive .

" It 's a long way . "[129-rachel]

" Oh , [Miss]3297-miss , "[142-janet] said [Jenny Harberton]142-janet timidly , " it 's not so very far . An ' it 's lovely when [you]131-janet get [there]377-there . [Father]144-father was [there]377-there last week , drivin ' [some officers]3300-some officers . [He]144-father says it _ is _ interestin ' ! "[142-janet]

[[Jenny]142-janet 's father]708-jenny 's father , [a plumber in [the village]304-the village]709-a plumber in the village , owned [a humble open car]711-a humble open car which was in perpetual request .

" There are [a hundred Canadians]3301-a hundred canadians apparently , "[131-janet] said [Janet Leighton]131-janet , looking at [her]131-janet letter , " and [German prisoners]3302-german prisoners , [quite a good few]3303-quite a good few , and [these thirty girls]3304-these thirty girls . [Rachel]129-rachel said nothing .

[Janet Leighton]131-janet dropped the subject for the moment , but after supper , with [her]131-janet writing - desk on [her]131-janet knee , [she]131-janet returned to it .

" Ca n't [you]131-janet go without [me]129-rachel ? "[129-rachel] said [Rachel]129-rachel , who was standing with [her]129-rachel back to [the room]431-the room , looking out of the window .

" So [I]129-rachel am . It is n't [the women]3158-the women . "[129-rachel]

" [The German prisoners]3308-the german prisoners , then ? "[131-janet] laughed [Janet]131-janet .

" Heavens , no ! "[129-rachel]

" Well , [I]129-rachel did n't have exactly a good time in [Canada]13-canada , "[129-rachel] [she]129-rachel said , as though the admission was dragged out of [her]129-rachel ; adding immediately , " but of course [I]129-rachel 'll go -- sometime -- after the harvest . "[129-rachel]

On which [she]129-rachel left [the room]431-the room , and presently [Janet]131-janet saw [her]129-rachel wandering among the stooks in the gloaming , [her]129-rachel hands behind [her]129-rachel back . [She]129-rachel seemed in [her]129-rachel ripe and comely youth to be somehow the very spirit of the harvest .

A little later , just before ten o'clock , while the sunset glow was still brooding on [the harvest fields]714-the harvest fields , [the two farm - girls]715-the two farm - girls , after a last visit to the cows , slipped into [the little sitting - room]716-the little sitting - room . [Janet]131-janet , who was mending [her]131-janet Sunday dress , greeted [them]715-the two farm - girls with a smile and a kind word . Then [she]131-janet moved to the table and took up a New Testament that was lying there . [She]131-janet was [an ardent and mystically - minded Unitarian]717-an ardent and mystically - minded unitarian , and [her]131-janet mind was much set towards religion .

" Shall [we]3309-we have prayers at night ? "[131-janet] [she]131-janet had said quite simply to [the f arm - girls]718-the f arm - girls on [their]715-the two farm - girls arrival . " Do n't if [you]718-the f arm - girls do n't want to . "[131-janet] And [they]715-the two farm - girls had shyly said " yes"--not[715-the two farm - girls] particularly attracted by the proposal , but willing to please [Miss Leighton]133-miss leighton , who was always nice to [them]715-the two farm - girls .

So [Janet]131-janet read some verses from the sixth chapter of [St. John]145-st. john : " Verily , verily , [I]145-st. john say unto [you]718-the f arm - girls , [he]3310-he that believeth on [Me]145-st. john hath everlasting life ... [I]145-st. john am the Bread of Life ... [I]145-st. john am the living Bread which came down from Heaven ... The words that [I]145-st. john speak unto [you]718-the f arm - girls [they]3311-they are spirit and they are life . "[145-st. john]

Closing the book , while [her]131-janet quiet eyes shone in the gleaming dusk , [she]131-janet said a few simple things about the Words of [Christ]146-christ , and how [the human soul]719-the human soul may feed on them -- the Word of Love -- the Word of Purity -- the Word of Service . While [she]131-janet was still speaking , the door opened and [Rachel]129-rachel came in . It had been agreed between [her]129-rachel and [Janet]131-janet that although [she]129-rachel had no objection to the prayers , [she]129-rachel was not to be asked to take part in them . So that [Janet]131-janet 's pulses fluttered a little when [she]131-janet appeared . But there was no outward sign of it . [The speaker]294-the speaker finished what [she]294-the speaker had to say , while the eyes of [[her]294-the speaker three hearers]721-her three hearers were sometimes on [her]294-the speaker face and sometimes on the wide cornfield beyond the open window , where the harvest moon , as yet only a brilliant sickle , was rising . [The Earth]23-the earth Bread without -- the " Bread of Life "[294-the speaker] within ; even in [Jenny]131-janet 's primitive mind , there was a mingling of the two ideas , which brought a quiet joy . [She]131-janet sat with parted lips , feeling that [she]131-janet liked [Miss Leighton]133-miss leighton very much , and would try to please [her]133-miss leighton with the cows .

[Betty]141-betty , meanwhile , beside [her]131-janet , passed into a waking dream . [She]141-betty was thinking of [a soldier in [the village]304-the village]722-a soldier in the village : [[the blacksmith]724-the blacksmith 's son]725-the blacksmith 's son , [a tall , handsome fellow , who had just arrived on leave for ten days]726-a tall , handsome fellow , who had just arrived on leave for ten days . [She]141-betty had spent Sunday evening wandering in [the lanes]727-the lanes with [him]725-the blacksmith 's son . [She]141-betty felt passionately that [she]141-betty must see [him]725-the blacksmith 's son again -- soon .

The little reading passed into [the Lord]3159-the lord 's Prayer . Then it was over and [the two girls]729-the two girls disappeared to bed . [Janet]131-janet felt a little awkward when [she]131-janet was left alone with [Rachel]129-rachel , but [she]131-janet went back to [her]131-janet sewing and began to talk of the day 's news of the war . [Rachel]129-rachel answered at random , and very soon said good - night .

But long after [everybody else]730-everybody else in [the solitary farmhouse]731-the solitary farmhouse was asleep , [Rachel Henderson]129-rachel was sitting up in bed , broad awake , [her]129-rachel hands round [her]129-rachel knees . The window beside [her]129-rachel was open . [She]129-rachel saw the side of [the hill]369-the hill and the bare down in which [it]369-the hill ended , with the moonlight bright upon [it]369-the hill , and the dark woods crowning [it]369-the hill . There were owls calling from [the hill]369-the hill , and every now and then a light wind rustled through the branches of an oak that stood in [the farm - yard]430-the farm - yard .

[She]129-rachel was thinking of what [Janet]131-janet had said about the " Words "[131-janet] of [Christ]146-christ -- the Word of Purity -- and the Word of Love . How often [she]131-janet had heard [[her]131-janet father]735-her father read and expound that chapter ! very differently as far as phraseology -- perhaps even as far as meaning -- went , yet with all [his]735-her father heart , like [Janet]131-janet . [He]735-her father was [an Anglican clergyman who had done missionary service in [the Canadian West]24-the canadian west]736-an anglican clergyman who had done missionary service in the canadian west . [He]735-her father had been dead now three years , and [[her]131-janet mother]354-her mother five . [She]131-janet had bitterly missed [them]738-them both when [she]131-janet was in [her]131-janet worst need ; yet now [she]131-janet was thankful [they]738-them had died -- before--

What would [[her]131-janet father]735-her father think of [her]131-janet now ? Would [he]735-her father grant that [she]131-janet was free , or would [he]735-her father still hold to those rigid , those cruel views of [his]735-her father ? Oh , [he]735-her father must grant it ! [She]131-janet _ was _ free ! [Her]131-janet breast shook with the fervour of [her]131-janet protest . [She]131-janet had been through passion and wrong , through things that seared and defiled . [She]131-janet knew well that [she]131-janet had been [no mere innocent sufferer]740-no mere innocent sufferer . Yet now [she]131-janet had [her]131-janet life before [her]131-janet again ; and both heart and senses were hungry for the happiness [she]131-janet had so abominably missed . And [her]131-janet starved conscience -- that , too , was eagerly awake . [She]131-janet had [her]131-janet self - respect to recover -- the past to forget .

_ Work _ ! that was the receipt -- hard work ! And [this dear woman]741-this dear woman , [Janet Leighton]131-janet , to help [her]131-janet ; [Janet]131-janet , with [her]131-janet pure , modest life and [her]131-janet high aims . So , at last , clinging to the thought of [[her]131-janet new friend]624-her new friend like [a wearied child]743-a wearied child , [Rachel Henderson]129-rachel fell asleep .

III

" A jolly view ! "[131-janet]

[Janet]131-janet assented . [She]131-janet was sitting behind [the pony]744-the pony , while [Rachel]129-rachel had walked up the hill beside [the carriage]347-the carriage , to the high point where both [she]131-janet and the pony -- [a lethargic specimen of the race]746-a lethargic specimen of the race -- had paused to take breath .

[They]747-they were on [a ridge]748-a ridge whence there was a broad bit of [the world]474-the world to see . To the north , [a plain rich in all the diversities of [English land]751-english land]750-a plain rich in all the diversities of english land -- field and wood , [hamlet]752-hamlet and [church]3267-church , the rising grounds and [shallow depressions]754-shallow depressions , the small enclosures and [the hedgerow timber]755-the hedgerow timber , that make all the difference between [the English midlands]756-the english midlands and , say , [the plain of [Champagne]25-champagne]757-the plain of champagne , or [a Russian steppe]758-a russian steppe . Across the wide , many - coloured scene , great clouds from the west were sweeping , with fringes of rain and sudden bursts of light or shadow , which in their perpetual movement -- suggesting attack from the sky and response from [the earth]759-the earth -- gave drama and symbol to [the landscape]760-the landscape .

On [the south]761-the south -- things very different ! First , [an interlocked range of hills , forest - clothed , stretching east and west]762-an interlocked range of hills , forest - clothed , stretching east and west , and , at the very feet of [the two women]763-the two women , [a forest valley]764-a forest valley offering much that was strange to English eyes . Two years before [it]764-a forest valley had been known only to [the gamekeeper]765-the gamekeeper and [the shooting guests of [a neighbouring landowner]767-a neighbouring landowner]766-the shooting guests of a neighbouring landowner . Now [a great timber camp]768-a great timber camp filled [it]764-a forest valley . [The gully]769-the gully ran far and deep into [the heart of [the forest country]771-the forest country]770-the heart of the forest country , with [a light railway]772-a light railway winding along the bottom , towards [an unseen road]773-an unseen road . [The steep sides of [the valley]775-the valley]774-the steep sides of the valley -- [Rachel]129-rachel and [Janet]131-janet stood on the edge of [one of [them]774-the steep sides of the valley]776-one of them -- were covered with felled trees , cut the preceding winter , and left as they fell . The dead branch and leaf of the trees had turned to a rich purple , and dyed all the inside of the long deep cup . But along [its]764-a forest valley edges stretched [the forest]777-the forest , still untouched , and everywhere , in the bare spaces left here and there by the felling among the " rubble and woody wreck , "[129-rachel] green and gold mosses and delicate grasses had sprung up , a brilliant enamel , inlaid with a multitude of wild flowers .

" Look ! "[129-rachel] cried [Rachel]129-rachel .

For suddenly , down below [them]778-them , a huge trunk began to move as though of its own accord . Hissing and crashing like some gray serpent , it glided down [the hill - side]779-the hill - side , till [it]764-a forest valley approached a group of figures and horses congregated at [the head of [the valley]775-the valley]780-the head of the valley , near an engine puffing smoke . Then something invisible happened , and presently a trolley piled high with logs detached itself from [the group]782-the group , and set out on a solitary journey down [the railway]783-the railway , watched here and there by [men in queer uniforms with patches on [their]784-men in queer uniforms with patches on their backs backs]784-men in queer uniforms with patches on their backs .

" [German prisoners]3302-german prisoners ! "[131-janet] said [Janet]131-janet , and strained [her]131-janet eyes to see , thinking all the time of a letter [she]131-janet had received that morning from [[her]131-janet soldier brother]785-her soldier brother fighting with [the English troops to [the west of [Rheims:--]26-rheims:--]787-the west of rheims:--]786-the english troops to the west of rheims:--

" [The beggars]3313-the beggars are on the run ! [Foch]147-foch has got [them]3313-the beggars this time . But , oh , [Lord]3314-lord , the sight [they]3313-the beggars 've made of all [this beautiful country]3315-this beautiful country ! Trampled , and ruined , and smashed ! all of it . ' How are [we]3313-the beggars ever going to live with [this people]3319-this people in [the same world]3320-the same world after the war ? "[786-the english troops to the west of rheims:--]

And there below , in [the heart of [this remote English woodland]789-this remote english woodland]788-the heart of this remote english woodland , now being sacrificed to the war , moved [the sons of [this very people , cast up here by the tide of battle]791-this very people , cast up here by the tide of battle]790-the sons of this very people , cast up here by the tide of battle . [Janet]131-janet had travelled a good deal in [Germany]29-germany before the war , using [her]131-janet holidays as [a mistress]800-a mistress in [a secondary school]801-a secondary school , and [her]131-janet small savings , in a kind of wandering which had been a passion with [her]131-janet . Yes , there was [the German camp]808-the german camp , and beyond [it]808-the german camp under [the hill [the Canadian forestry camp]810-the canadian forestry camp]809-the hill the canadian forestry camp ; whilst just beneath [them]806-them could be seen the roof of [the large women 's hostel]811-the large women 's hostel .

" But have n't [you]129-rachel seen all this before ? "[131-janet] asked [Janet]131-janet .

" No , [I]129-rachel never saw anything of lumbering . "[129-rachel]

The tone showed the sudden cooling and reserve that were always apparent in [Rachel]129-rachel 's manner when [any subject connected with [Canada]13-canada]814-any subject connected with canada came into conversation . Yet [Janet]131-janet had noticed with surprise that it was [Rachel]129-rachel [herself]129-rachel who , when the harvest was nearly over , had revived the subject of [the camp]3224-the camp , and planned the drive for this Saturday afternoon . [The rough road on which [they]806-them were driving]816-the rough road on which they were driving wound gradually downward through the felled timber . [Rachel]129-rachel was aware of a thin , handsome face bronzed by exposure , a pair of blue eyes , rather pale in colour , to which the sunburn of brow and cheek gave a singular brilliance , and a well - cut , determined mouth . For talk , indeed , the business in hand was far too strenuous . The logs were coming in fast ; there must be no slip in measurement or note . The work was hard , and [the women doing it]844-the women doing it had been at it all day . "[847-the captain]

[He]851-he looked at [her]852-her with sparkling eyes , and [her]852-her face involuntarily answered the challenge of [his]851-he ; so much so that [his]851-he look prolonged itself . [His]847-the captain smile was friendly , and [Rachel]129-rachel found it pleasant to be advised by [him]847-the captain . [He]847-the captain glanced at [her]129-rachel curiously . " Well , if [I]847-the captain came across [these fellows]3391-these fellows jeering at [an Englishwoman]3392-an englishwoman , [I]847-the captain 'd know the reason why ! "[847-the captain] [he]847-the captain resumed hotly . " [You]129-rachel should have complained . "[847-the captain]
